Literature Review: The intricate relationship between the nervous system and cancer has emerged as a critical area of research in recent years. This literature review explores the complex neuroepithelial interactions in cancer, focusing on the role of nerves in tumor development, progression, and potential therapeutic interventions.Nerves play a crucial role in regulating the homeostasis and energetic metabolism of normal epithelial cells. Interestingly, cancer cells appear to recapitulate this neural regulation of epithelial tissues, suggesting a fundamental link between nervous system function and cancer biology (Magnon et al., 2013). The importance of innervation in cancer development is underscored by the observation that cancer rarely develops in denervated organs, and surgical or chemical denervation can significantly affect tumorigenesis both in animal models and human patients (Zhao et al., 2014).One of the key processes in neuroepithelial interactions during cancer progression is axonogenesis, the growth of new nerve fibers. As tumors develop, they stimulate the growth of new nerves to supply the malignant epithelial growth with innervation. This process is thought to be mediated by various neurotrophic factors secreted by cancer cells, creating a supportive microenvironment for nerve growth (Boilly et al., 2017). The newly formed nerve fibers not only provide trophic support to the tumor but also serve as conduits for the spread of cancer cells, facilitating metastasis.Following axonogenesis, neurogenesis occurs in the surrounding tissues. This process involves the formation of new neurons, initially in ganglia around organs or the spinal column, and subsequently through the recruitment of neuroblasts from the central nervous system (Mauffrey et al., 2019). The hallmark of this stage is the regulation of homeostasis and energetic metabolism in the tumor microenvironment, which can significantly influence cancer cell survival and proliferation.Perineural invasion (PNI) represents one of the most efficient interactions between cancer cells and nerves. During PNI, cancer cells invade the perineural space and use nerve fibers as a route for local and distant spread. This process is associated with increased proliferation and decreased apoptosis of cancer cells, contributing to tumor progression and poor clinical outcomes (Amit et al., 2016). The molecular mechanisms underlying PNI are complex and involve bidirectional signaling between cancer cells and nerves, mediated by various growth factors, chemokines, and adhesion molecules.In the final stage of neuroepithelial interactions, some carcinoma cells undergo transdifferentiation, acquiring a neuronal-like phenotype. This process, known as neuron-like transdifferentiation, represents an attempt by cancer cells to achieve neural independence (Gao et al., 2019). By adopting neuronal characteristics, these cells may gain the ability to produce their own growth factors and neurotransmitters, potentially reducing their dependence on external neural input for survival and proliferation.The growing understanding of neuroepithelial interactions in cancer has significant implications for cancer treatment strategies. Traditional approaches focusing solely on targeting cancer cells may be insufficient, given the critical role of the nervous system in tumor biology. Novel therapeutic interventions that address the neural regulation of cancer are being explored, including pharmacological agents that modulate neurotransmitter signaling or inhibit neurotrophin receptors (Renz et al., 2018).Denervation strategies, either surgical or chemical, have shown promise in preclinical studies and some clinical settings. For instance, vagotomy has been associated with reduced risk of gastric cancer in human patients, highlighting the potential of targeting nerve-cancer interactions as a preventive or therapeutic approach (Zhao et al., 2014). However, the systemic effects of broad denervation must be carefully considered, and more targeted approaches may be necessary to minimize side effects.Another promising avenue of research involves the development of therapies that specifically disrupt the communication between nerves and cancer cells. This could include targeting the signaling molecules involved in axonogenesis and neurogenesis or developing agents that prevent perineural invasion (Deborde et al., 2018). Additionally, strategies to inhibit neuron-like transdifferentiation of cancer cells may help prevent the development of neural independence and potentially improve treatment outcomes.In conclusion, the field of neuroepithelial interactions in cancer represents a rapidly evolving area of research with significant implications for our understanding of cancer biology and the development of novel therapeutic approaches. As our knowledge of the complex interplay between nerves and cancer cells continues to grow, it is becoming increasingly clear that addressing the neural regulation of cancer will be crucial for developing more effective and comprehensive treatment strategies. Future research should focus on elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying these interactions and translating this knowledge into clinically applicable interventions that target the nervous system-cancer axis.
